titleStmt.title: The Kings Majesties remonstrance to his subjects of England, touching the great worke, and present affaires of the Kingdome; consisting of eight severall branches; sent from the Kings most Excellent Majesty now resident in the Isle of Wheight and subscribed, Charles Rex. Together with His Majesties proposition to Colonel Hammond (Governour of the said island) concerning His Royall Person, the Army, and Kingdome. And the Governours answer thereunto. With a copy of the new protestation, to be tendred to each respective regiment throughout the Army. Imprimatur, Gilb. Mabbott.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: LONDON, Printed by J.C. for G. HORTON, 1647.

div.head: His Maje≈øties la≈øt MESSAGE TO The Lords and Commons a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament, to be communicated to His Subiects of Scotland.
Sent in a Letter from His Maje≈øties Court in the J≈øle of Wight, Novemb. 20. 1647.
div.p: HIs Maje≈øty is ≈øomewhat more plea≈øanter, then at His fir≈øt comming, and begins to recreat him≈øelf, taking his plea≈øure abroad in the I≈øland, both in hunting, and other delightfull Sports, being much ≈øati fied in mind, touching his entertainment in this I≈øland. Mo≈øt of the Gentry, that are re≈øident here, hath vi≈øited the Court, and divers beene admitted to ki≈ø≈øe his Maje≈øties hand.

Great joy is made throughout the whole I≈øland, at his Maje≈øties ≈øafe arrivall, and much loyalty ≈øhewed by the Inhabitants thereof, e≈øpecially by the Gentry of Newport, who at his Maje≈øties coming to that Towne, entertained his Royall Per≈øon very gallantly, and declared them≈øelves with much loyalty, promi≈øing ≈øecurity to his Maje≈øties Per≈øon, and to pre≈øerve and defend His gracious Maje≈øty from all danger what≈øoever.

His Maje≈øty hath declared his gracious will and plea≈øure to our Governour, touching the re≈øpective Regiments in the Army, who hath divided and ≈øeparated them≈øelves from the obedience and command of the Generall, A Copy whereof I have here ≈øent you inclo≈øed; together with his Maje≈øties Propo≈øals to both Hou≈øes of Parliament, both which I have hereunto annexed, viz.

HAmmond, after an intollerable re≈øtraint to my Per≈øon it Hampton Court, I found there was a further de≈øigne again≈øt my per≈øon by a dividing party in the Armie; and having an earne≈øt de≈øi ‚Ä¢ e of ≈øetling of the Kingdome, in ≈øuch ≈øort as might be≈øt conduce to a la≈øting peace throughout my Dominions, and not to be an in≈øtrument of ≈øtirring up a new war, I have thought good to declare, that I am confident of your fidelity in protecting my per≈øon from danger, untill by ≈øuch addre≈ø≈øes as ≈øhall be made unto Us by the parliament, there be a mutuall agreement concluded, and Our Kingdome ≈øetled.

To which our Govervour replied, that he tend ered his Maje≈øties per≈øon above his own life, and would not fai ‚Ä¢ e i ‚Ä¢ doing his utmo≈øt in fulfilling his M ‚Ä¢ je≈øties De≈øires, in relation to the orders and directions which he ≈øhould receive from the Parliament.
Then his Maje≈øty proceeded on in ≈øending new propo≈øitions to the Parliament, the chiefe heads whereof, I have here ≈øent you inclo≈øed, viz.

1. His Maje≈øty conceives him≈øelf bound not to aboli≈øh Epi≈øcopacie, both as he is a Chri≈øtian, and as he i ‚Ä¢ a King; As he is a Chri≈øtian, it being in≈øtituted by Chri≈øt and his Apo≈øtles: And as he is a King, being bound to maintaine them by the Oath which he ≈øwore at his Coronation; And by them the Doctrine of Religion, the Government and Di≈øcipline of the Church, which hath under his predece≈ø≈øours been maintained.
2. For ≈øale of the Bi≈øhops Lands, his Maje≈øty holds it high ≈øacriledge, they hav ‚Ä¢ ng been given to them by divers Benefactors.

3. His Maje≈øtie offers to call in all his Proclamations, and Declarations, again≈øt the parliament and tho≈øe who have adhered to them; and will give order for withdrawing all Inditements again≈øt tho≈øe who have adhered to the Part. And his Maje≈øty offers to pa≈ø≈øe an Act of Indempnity and generall pardon.

4. For the A ‚Ä¢ mie, his Maje≈øty undertakes with the monies received, and due, and to be received out of Seque≈øtrations, to pay 400000. l. for payment of the Army their Arreares; and if it will not do it, his Maje≈øty will make it up out of Forre≈øt Lands.
5. His Maje≈øtie is content to part with the Mili i ‚Ä¢ of the Kingdom, during his own life, but t ‚Ä¢ a after his Reigne; it may return again ‚Ä¢ o its proper place.

6. For the publigue Debts of the Kingdome, his Maje≈øtie will conferre wi ‚Ä¢ h his two Hou≈øes of parliament for the payment of them. And his Maj. is content to confirm ‚Ä¢ ≈øuch Officers of State, as the two Hou≈øes of parliament ≈øh ‚Ä¢ ll nominate, ctc. 7. That the Propo≈øals of the Army be taken into con≈øideration by the two Hou≈øes of parliament.
8. That his M ‚Ä¢ je ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ y be admitted to come to London, to con≈øult with his Parliament, for the ≈øetling of a firme and la≈øting peace.

Sir, Thus have I given you the chiefe ≈øub≈øtance of his Maje≈øties Propo≈øitions, ≈øent to the Lords and Commons a≈ø≈øembled at We≈øtmin≈øter, &c. as al≈øo the late circum≈øtances, which pa≈ø≈øed betwixt the Kings Maje≈øty, and our Governor, being all at pre≈øent, from

closer.signed: Your mo≈øt affectionate friend, Edward Baynton.

dateline.hi: Newport, in the J≈øle of Wight,

div.head: The Copy of a Letter from the Army, touching the proceedings of the Souldicry.
div.p:
THe late proceedings of the Army, at their Randezvouze betwixt Hartford and Ware, tends much to unity and concord, and a mo≈øt happy complyance begins to take impre≈ø≈øion in the hearts of the Majorality, for the ≈øtorme is almo≈øt over, and the di≈ømall Cloud di≈ø≈øolved, for tho≈øe who appeared, and ≈øeemed mo≈øt forward in the late Engagement, begins now to be vi≈øible in a contrary character, and hath declared very unanimou≈øly to
be conformable and obedient to the commands of the Generall, being re≈øolved to ≈øub≈øcribe to the late Prote≈øtation, agreed upon by his Excellency, and his Councell of War, a copy whereof I have here ≈øent you inclo≈øed. Tho≈øe Regiments which ≈øeemed mo≈øt oppo≈øite and refractory again≈øt the Generalls commands, were col. Harri≈øons and col. Lilburnes, who appeared in the field in a very ≈øtrange po≈øture, ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ing quite cont ‚Ä¢ ary to their former principles, The Generall declared him≈øelf very ≈øatisfactory at the head of each Regiment, which gave great content to the Soul ‚Ä¢ iery, in≈øomuch that a happy complyance proceeded throughout the greate≈øt part of the Army, for continuance whereof, is the earne≈øt de≈øire of

div.head: The Prote≈øtation
div.p:
VVEE the Officers and Souldiers of _____ Regiment of _____ who≈øe Names are ≈øub≈øcribed, do hereby declare, That wee are ≈øatisfied in his Excellency, the Generall, continued conjuction with the Army, in the lawfull, pro≈øecution of
the things formerly declared, to be pro≈øecuted for the Souldiery and Kingdome re≈øpectively‚ñ™ And (for the particular circum≈øtances of them) we ≈øhall (according to the generall Engagement of the Army above mentioned) acquie≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢ in what ≈øhall be agreed unto by the Generall Councell of the Army, to which that Engagement referres; and for matter of the ordering, conduct, and government of the Army, we ≈øhall be ob≈øervant of, and ≈øubject to his Excellencie, his Councell of Warre, and (every one of us) to our Superiour Officers in this Regiment and the Army, according to the Di≈øcipline of Warre.
